Award.AwardTitle: Implementation of a relational database for the Sternberg Museum paleontology collection
Award.AbstractNarration:
Fort Hays State University's Sternberg Museum of Natural History (FHSM) is awarded a grant to digitized, image, curate, and archive paleontology specimen data into a centralized and publically accessible database. FHSM serves as a major public fossil repository and educational institution. The paleontology collection represents over 100 years of fossil collecting and includes vertebrate and invertebrate holdings that are critical for understanding past life in the Great Plains. The specimens are used extensively in research and as the basis for educational programs and exhibits. Many specimens within the collection have been donated by local landowners and need to be fully curated and integrated into the collection. Additionally, the collection lacks a digital database and no specimen data are available online. This project will digitally preserve irreplaceable data and make specimen data (including images) available online for the first time. The digitization and sharing of these data will provide researchers, educators, students, and the general public with easy access to the collection, benefitting a broad audience.

Funding ensures that digital records of FHSM specimens are properly achieved and easily accessible for research and educational uses. Project goals include transcribing hand-written records, building a relational database with online platform, integrating data and metadata into existing research databases, curating backlogged specimens, 2D and 3D imaging of fossil specimens, and developing educational resources. All paleontology specimens and specimen data will be digitized and databased into CollectiveAccess data management system, which is being adopted to house collection data. The application of modern collection management standards will enable researchers and educators from around the world access to specimen data. The Sternberg Museum provides science education for a large, yet rural, region, making online access to material imperative to the educational mission of the Museum. This project will also employ multiple Fort Hays State University graduate and undergraduate students over a three-year period. These students will be trained in curatorial and research techniques using the specimens digitized during the course of this project. Overall, this project will greatly enhance the significance of the FHSM paleontology collection by improving organization, accessibility, and research and education potential. Additional information about the paleontology collection at the Sternberg Museum can be found at http://sternberg.fhsu.edu/research-collections/collections/paleontology/.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
Situated in rural Kansas, Fort Hays State University’s Sternberg Museum of Natural History (FHSM) serves as a major public fossil repository and educational institution for the region. The paleontology collection includes more than 22,300 specimen lots representing more than 400,000 individual vertebrate and invertebrate fossils, mostly representing past ecosystems from Kansas and the Central Great Plains. The Museum is an exceptional repository for Cretaceous marine fossils, and these collections are an invaluable resource for researchers interested in Cretaceous marine ecosystems and are prominently featured in Museum exhibits. Neogene and Pleistocene terrestrial mammals documenting the evolution of the Great Plains grasslands also make up significant portions of the collection.  The ultimate goal of this project was to bring the Sternberg Museum’s paleontology collection up-to-date with modern collections management protocol by digitizing and making data accessible online. Specific goals included customizing and implementing a relational database, transcribing and archiving data, capturing 2D and 3D images of fossils, sharing digitized information with relevant communities, and creating educational resources using the Museum’s collection. 

Data records for all specimens in the paleontology collection were transcribed from hand-written records, cross-checked for accuracy; physical specimens were checked to ensure they are properly organized and housed within the collection. 12,209 research-quality 2D images were taken of invertebrate (2572 photographs) and vertebrate (9637 photographs) fossil specimens. Seventy-five 3D images were captured of 23 type specimens using either a 3D scanner or photogrammetry. All data and images are now archived in a customized relational database (CollectiveAccess) for long-term storage. Over the course of this project, the Sternberg Museum was also able to provide funding and/or professional development to fourteen Fort Hays State University undergraduate and graduate students; many of these students are now employed full-time by museums or are in graduate programs.

Sternberg Museum fossil data and images are openly available on the Museum’s online database (https://sternbergca.fhsu.edu/) and data aggregators like iDigBio and MorphoSource, making the collection available to researchers, educators, students, and the general public worldwide.  FHSM paleontology staff worked with the regional PBS station to create museum-focused educational programming for a general audience. In association with this grant FHSM also partnered with Fort Hays State University’s Science and Mathematics Education Institute to provide a teacher workshop (“Museum Data in the Classroom”) to work with Kansas science teachers on how to incorporate digital natural history resources into their classrooms. Educational materials produced in association with this project are all available open access on the Sternberg Museum’s website.


Last Modified: 01/14/2021
Modified by: Laura E Wilson

The paleontology collection includes more than 22,300 specimen lots representing more than 400,000 individual vertebrate and invertebrate fossils, mostly representing past ecosystems from Kansas and the Central Great Plains. Neogene and Pleistocene terrestrial mammals documenting the evolution of the Great Plains grasslands also make up significant portions of the collection. Specific goals included customizing and implementing a relational database, transcribing and archiving data, capturing 2D and 3D images of fossils, sharing digitized information with relevant communities, and creating educational resources using the Museum’s collection. Data records for all specimens in the paleontology collection were transcribed from hand-written records, cross-checked for accuracy; physical specimens were checked to ensure they are properly organized and housed within the collection. 12,209 research-quality 2D images were taken of invertebrate (2572 photographs) and vertebrate (9637 photographs) fossil specimens. Over the course of this project, the Sternberg Museum was also able to provide funding and/or professional development to fourteen Fort Hays State University undergraduate and graduate students; many of these students are now employed full-time by museums or are in graduate programs. Sternberg Museum fossil data and images are openly available on the Museum’s online database (https://sternbergca.fhsu.edu/) and data aggregators like iDigBio and MorphoSource, making the collection available to researchers, educators, students, and the general public worldwide. FHSM paleontology staff worked with the regional PBS station to create museum-focused educational programming for a general audience. In association with this grant FHSM also partnered with Fort Hays State University’s Science and Mathematics Education Institute to provide a teacher workshop ("Museum Data in the Classroom") to work with Kansas science teachers on how to incorporate digital natural history resources into their classrooms.
